user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *string)
{
    void *                  addrbuffer;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in.sin_addr;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_addr;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    /* This function is defined as returning 1 on success, not 0 */
    if (inet_pton(Accessor->sa.sa_family, string, addrbuffer) != 1)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in the function modifies a function parameter itself. Specifically:
- The parameter Addr is only read (used in the expression &Addr->AddrData and to access Addr->AddrData.sa.sa_family). There is no assignment to Addr (no statements like Addr = ..., Addr++, or similar), so the pointer parameter is not modified.
- The parameter string is declared const and is only passed to inet_pton; it is not assigned to or otherwise modified in the function.
- The only modification that may occur is via inet_pton(…, addrbuffer), which writes into the object pointed to by addrbuffer. That object is Addr->AddrData (accessed through the local pointer Accessor). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is allowed by Rule 17.8; only modifying the pointer parameter itself is forbidden.
- All other operations are local (assignments to local variables addrbuffer and Accessor, switch on a member value, and returns) and do not alter the parameter identifiers.
Therefore there are no fragments that warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
